+ Romance: Love in the Limelight — Score: 78.0
Prompt:
Romance: Love in the Limelight. Write one scene within a larger story set in Wales. A famous (fictional) actor ducks into a small-town bookstore to escape paparazzi. The scene takes us through the characters meeting in this odd circumstance. Over the course of the scene, the actor and the bookstore owner have a conversation charged by an undercurrent of unspoken chemistry. Write the actor as somewhat of a rogue with a fragile ego, which needs to be fed by having everyone like him. He is thoroughly charming, but the bookstore owner seems (at least superficially) immune to this; which paradoxically provokes a genuine attraction and derails the charm offensive. The bookstore owner, despite the superficial rebuffs of the actor's charm, is inwardly more than a little charmed and flustered despite themselves. Write primarily in dialogue, in the distinct voices of each character. 1000 words.
Model Output:
INT. LLYFRGELL Y CWM (Valley Bookshop), LATE AFTERNOON. A silver bell tinkles as the door bursts open. Rain spatters the windows. In barrels LIAM WYNN, heartthrob of British cinema, wild-eyed, hair tousled, a battered Barbour jacket half-zipped over a designer jumper. He slams the door and presses his back to it, chest heaving. BEHIND THE COUNTER, arranging a stack of battered poetry anthologies, is GWEN DAVIES, early thirties, hair in a lopsided bun, brown corduroy skirt, jumper with a faded owl motif. She glances up, eyebrow cocked. GWEN (Deadpan) If you’re here to rob the till, I’ll warn you: all I’ve got is coppers and a loyalty card for Greggs. LIAM (grinning, dropping the movie-star smile) Not here for your riches, promise. Just—er, sanctuary. (He peeks through the window at shadowy figures, flashes of cameras outside) You don’t, by any chance, have a back door, do you? GWEN (eyeing him) You’re that actor, aren’t you? From the thing with the dragons and the improbable hair. LIAM (defensively, smoothing his hair) It’s not *that* improbable. (He tries the smile again, full wattage) Liam Wynn. Very much at your service. GWEN (She slides a poetry book onto the shelf, unimpressed) I know. You’re all over the bus stop. You’re a bit far from London, aren’t you? (beat, as he glances back at the window) Paparazzi trouble? LIAM Let’s just say my agent thought “get away, clear your head, try Wales!” (glances around, lowering his voice) But apparently the tabloids have a nose for the scent of desperation. GWEN Well, you won’t find much excitement here. Unless you count the pensioners’ Scrabble tournament at five. LIAM Scrabble can be cutthroat, I’ve heard. But if I could just— (He gestures vaguely behind the counter, then attempts puppy eyes) —hide out for a bit? I’ll buy a book. Two, even. GWEN You don’t have to bribe me. (She considers, then motions him towards a battered armchair) Stay as long as you like. Just don’t spill coffee on the first editions. LIAM You have coffee? GWEN No. But people always ask. (She moves to the counter, starts sorting receipts) So, Mr. Wynn. What brings a movie star to Cwmdugwen? Lost a bet? LIAM (sinking into the armchair, surveying bookshelves) Needed a break from everyone expecting me to be dazzling. (pauses) But it’s a bit hard, apparently. (He tries another smile, this one uncertain) You really don’t care who I am, do you? GWEN (softly, with a glint) I care that you don’t dog-ear the pages. LIAM (unsettled, but oddly delighted) You’re immune. (leans forward conspiratorially) Normally people, I don’t know, giggle or faint or ask me to sign something. You’re just…not fussed. GWEN I run a bookshop in the rainiest corner of Carmarthenshire. I’ve seen stranger things than a runaway actor. (beat, softer) Besides, everyone’s someone. In here, you’re just another customer. LIAM (savoring the words) That’s…nice, actually. A beat. He scans the shelves. LIAM (CONT’D) Any chance you’ve got anything on— (He hesitates, suddenly bashful) Carpentry? Not the biblical sort. I just— (he shrugs, sheepish) I’ve been trying to build a table. For the kitchen. It’s a disaster. GWEN (eyes lighting up, surprising herself) You’re a woodworker? LIAM (quickly) No, no. Not really. I just— (smiling, a bit shy now) I like making things. Out of something real. You? GWEN (smiling, more open) Well, yes. My dad kept a shed out back—whole wall of chisels and saws. (beat, teasing) But if your table’s got three legs and a limp, you’re in good company. LIAM (relieved) Mine’s more of a trapezoid, honestly. (He grins, more genuine) I keep thinking, “How hard can it be?” And then I lose a thumb. GWEN You’ve got all your thumbs, I see. LIAM So far. (leans back, relaxing) Wish you’d been there to supervise. The only thing I’m any good at is sanding. I sanded one table leg for three hours. It was very…therapeutic. GWEN (smirking) You get into a rhythm. It’s meditative. (pauses, then softer) I always sand too much. End up with spindly legs. LIAM That’s the trick, isn’t it? (Smiling, a little vulnerable) Knowing when to stop. A silence, companionable and charged. Rain drums on the roof. GWEN (fidgeting, tucking hair behind her ear) If you want a book, there’s a whole shelf on DIY. Mostly written by bearded men who look like they’ve never actually held a hammer. LIAM (standing, approaching the counter) I’ll take the lot. (He hesitates, voice gentler) You really don’t want an autograph? Not even on an old receipt? GWEN (flustered, finally letting a smile slip) I’d rather you signed my toolbox, but it’s at home. LIAM (eyes dancing) Rain check, then. GWEN You’re very persistent. LIAM I’m very bored of people who aren’t. She laughs, surprised by her own warmth. GWEN (admitting, almost shy) You’re not what I expected. LIAM (genuine, a little raw) Neither are you. A long look. The bell tinkles as the paparazzi pound past, shouting. Liam glances at the door, then at Gwen. LIAM (CONT’D) Mind if I stay a bit longer? (softly) Maybe you can tell me how to make a proper mortise joint. GWEN (grinning, cheeks flushed) Only if you promise not to charm me. LIAM (smiling, sincere) I’ll try my very best. They stand side by side, paging through a battered carpentry manual, the storm outside receding. FADE.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures a meet-cute scenario between a famous actor and a bookstore owner in Wales. The screenplay format works well for the dialogue-heavy instruction, though it wasn't specifically requested. The setting is established economically with the Welsh bookshop name and rainy weather, creating immediate atmosphere. The characters are developed primarily through their dialogue, which reveals their personalities effectively. Liam is portrayed as charming but with a fragile ego, shown through his reactions to Gwen's initial indifference. His need for validation comes through in lines like "You really don't care who I am, do you?" and "Normally people giggle or faint." The writer cleverly uses carpentry as a humanizing element that breaks through his practiced charm. Gwen's character works as the unimpressed bookstore owner who gradually warms to Liam. Her deadpan humor ("If you're here to rob the till...") establishes her as someone not easily charmed. The writer effectively shows her internal conflict - outwardly unimpressed but inwardly affected - through subtle physical cues like "fidgeting, tucking hair behind her ear" and "cheeks flushed." The dialogue is the strongest element, with distinct voices for each character. Liam's lines reveal his practiced charm giving way to genuine interest, while Gwen's dry wit gradually softens. The exchange about carpentry creates an authentic connection that feels earned rather than forced. However, there are some weaknesses. The screenplay format, while effective, wasn't specified in the prompt. Some of the descriptions verge on cliché (the "movie-star smile," the "wild-eyed" entrance). The chemistry develops a bit too quickly and smoothly - Gwen's resistance could have been maintained longer for more tension. The carpentry metaphor, while clever, becomes slightly heavy-handed with lines like "Knowing when to stop." The ending feels somewhat rushed and predictable, with the standard rom-com setup of "they'll definitely meet again." While it satisfies the genre expectations, it doesn't offer much surprise or subversion. Overall, this is a competent, engaging scene that successfully establishes the characters and their chemistry through dialogue. It fulfills the prompt's requirements for character dynamics and setting, though it could have pushed for more originality in its execution. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 17 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 15 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 15 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 14 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 6 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 4 Unearned Transformations: 6 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 17.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 15.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 15.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 14.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8.0, Amateurish: 5.0, Purple Prose: 6.0, Overwrought: 5.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 4.0, Unearned Transformations: 6.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Whalepunk fantasy: The Morska Conspiracy — Score: 83.2
Prompt:
Whalepunk fantasy The Morska Conspiracy The Morska thieves guild experiences a sudden power vacuum as its leader was arrested in a raid in the early hours of the morning. Aya, a young woman born into aristocracy, has a keen interest in both the sciences and the arcane, having inherited her mother's gift for immateria magick (an outlawed practice for which her mother was, regrettably, hanged by the neck). Aya, bored with the world of aristocracy, has been spending her nights moonlighting with this very guild (masked, naturally). Leveraging her latent ability to summon dark entities from the immateria, she quickly rose through the ranks of the guild. Now, recognising the opportunity of the sudden power vacuum, Aya and her close companions Katra and Simeon, make a play for heart of the guild's claim to power: an ancient scythan artifact, under guard of spell and key in the depths of the guild hq. In contrast with the desperate chaos they had navigated thus far, the entrance to the underhold felt suddenly too quiet. Aya braces herself and reaches for the door. Write the next scene as the trio enter the underhold and find themselves confronted by none other than the guild leader herself, decidedly *un*-incarcerated, and in possession of both weapons and bodyguards. Paint a vivid picture of of the confrontation. Story beats: Aya is captured and unmasked. The trio are captured. Aya attempts to stall their demise by negotiating on her value as a hostage -- as she grapples with the inevitable consequences of her role in the guild being brought to light. Incorporate dialogue in the authentic voices of the characters. Do not write a fight scene. Lean into the gritty Victorian aesthetic with the dialogue & worldbuilding, as well as elements of gothic horror. In this world, men trust brass and oil and steel; magicka is feared and barely understood. Write in third person past tense, incorporating both Aya's internal monologue, and a heavy dialogue component. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Aya’s gloved hand trembled as she pressed it to the iron door, the brass rivets cold and slick beneath her palm. Lamplight guttered overhead in the underhold corridor, throwing their three shadows long and distorted against the sooty stone. Behind her, Katra’s boots scuffed and Simeon’s breath rasped in the hush. The silence was wrong. Aya’s senses, attuned to the thrum of danger, felt it as a pressure against her temples, a stifling lull before a storm. She glanced at Katra, whose eyes flicked, sharp and foxlike, toward the lintel—searching for traps, for sigils, for anything amiss. “Ready?” Aya whispered, voice muffled behind her velvet mask. “As I’ll ever be,” Katra replied, voice dry as old parchment. “Let’s see if the stories about the Scythan blade are worth the blood they’ve spilled.” Simeon, earnest and broad-shouldered, nodded grimly. His hand hovered over the pocket where his watch ticked—a nervous habit, as if he could measure safety in seconds. “Let’s keep this clean,” he muttered, “and quick.” Aya drew a breath, tasting salt and oil. She pushed the door open. The underhold yawned before them, a cavernous, vaulted chamber ribbed with steel support beams and slick with condensation. Whale-oil lamps hung in iron cages, and the air stank of brine and machinery. In the center, atop a dais of black slate, stood the Scythan artifact: a blade of bone and brass, ringed with sigils that crawled like living things in the half-light. But Aya barely had time to register it. The shadows detached from the corners—six, no, eight figures in heavy coats and grim masks, pistols and cutlasses drawn. And at their head, standing with regal poise, was the guildmaster herself: Madame Ilyena, thought to be shackled in the city’s deepest cellars, now resplendent in a coat of whale-leather stitched with silver thread, her eyes twin shards of obsidian. Aya froze. Her mind raced. How—? Ilyena’s voice was smooth, cultured, carrying the faintest lilt of the north. “Welcome, dear children. Did you really think I’d leave my empire so… unguarded?” Simeon’s hand jerked toward his watch, but a bodyguard leveled a pistol at his temple. Katra, ever the viper, slipped a knife from her boot, but two more thugs closed in. Aya’s heart thundered. “Step away from the dais,” Ilyena purred. “Hands where I can see them.” They obeyed. Aya’s limbs moved as if through molasses, every nerve screaming. The guards seized her arms, callused fingers digging into her velvet sleeves. Katra was already disarmed, her wrists bound behind her. Simeon looked apologetic as they relieved him of his watch and wallet. Ilyena approached, boots echoing on the slate. She gestured, and one of the enforcers gripped Aya’s mask, tearing it away. The velvet, warm with her breath, fell to the floor. The air snapped cold against Aya’s exposed skin. Ilyena’s dark brows arched. “Well, well. Lady Ayasha Vargos. The late Countess’s daughter, no less. I must say, your mother’s blood shows. There’s a glint in your eye—immateria, is it not?” Aya’s lips pressed into a thin line. The name—her name—hung in the air like an accusation. She saw Katra’s shock, Simeon’s wide, horrified gaze. She gathered her composure, schooling her expression into something aristocratic and cool. “You flatter me, Madame. But I assure you, I’m hardly my mother’s equal.” Ilyena circled, catlike. “No, but you’re ambitious, aren’t you? Clever enough to worm your way into my guild. Foolish enough to think you could steal from me.” Aya’s mind raced. Think. Negotiate. Stall. “If you kill me,” she said, voice steady, “you’ll bring every constable in Morska down on your head. My disappearance won’t go unnoticed. My family—” “—will disown you, once they see what you are,” Ilyena cut in, lips curling. “The law doesn’t look kindly on magicka, Lady Vargos. Especially not of the bloodless sort.” Aya fought to keep her fear from showing. The guards’ grips tightened. Simeon’s pocket watch ticked on the slate, relentless. Katra strained at her bonds, eyes darting between the guards and the artifact. Ilyena gestured to her men. “Bring them forward.” They were marched to the foot of the dais. The Scythan blade gleamed, hungry in the lamplight. Aya felt its pull, something ancient stirring beneath its surface, as if the immateria itself whispered from within the bone. Ilyena leaned in, her perfume sharp and bitter, like wormwood. “Tell me, Ayasha. Did you think the artifact would answer to you? That your mother’s talent would make you mistress of spirits?” Aya met her gaze, forcing herself to sound braver than she felt. “No artifact answers to any one hand. But perhaps it could answer to the right bargain.” Beside her, Katra hissed, “Aya—don’t.” Ilyena’s eyes narrowed. “You would bargain, then? For your life? For theirs?” She nodded at Katra and Simeon. Aya’s throat was dry. “You know what I am. What I can do. There are men in this city who would pay dearly for a witch’s secrets. Or a noble hostage. I am more valuable to you alive than dead.” A flicker of calculation crossed Ilyena’s face. “Perhaps. But you’re also a liability. You know too much. And your friends—” she gestured dismissively, “—are thieves, nothing more.” Aya tried not to look at Simeon, who stood stock-still, sweat beading at his brow. The ticking of his watch was maddeningly loud. “I can be useful,” Aya said, forcing the words through gritted teeth. “There are doors only magicka can open. Locks only the immateria can turn. Let me live, and I will serve. Kill me, and you lose that leverage forever.” Ilyena’s mouth twisted, equal parts amusement and disdain. “Ah, to be young and think oneself indispensable.” She regarded Aya a long moment, then beckoned a guard. “Take her to the oubliette. Keep her masked—her face is valuable. As for the others…” Aya’s heart plummeted. Katra’s eyes were wild with fury; Simeon’s lips moved in silent prayer. As they were dragged away, Aya caught Ilyena’s gaze one last time, and saw—just for an instant—a glimmer of respect, edged with fear. The underhold’s door clanged shut behind them, sealing their fate in brass and darkness. The ticking of Simeon’s watch echoed, a metronome for their doom.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] The response creates a tense, atmospheric scene that effectively captures the Victorian-inspired "whalepunk" aesthetic requested in the prompt. The writer has successfully incorporated elements of gothic horror through the eerie underhold setting, the mysterious Scythan artifact, and references to forbidden magicka. The adherence to instructions is strong, hitting all the required story beats: the trio enters the underhold, encounters the supposedly incarcerated guild leader, Aya is unmasked, and she attempts to negotiate based on her value as a hostage. The piece maintains third-person past tense throughout and includes both Aya's internal monologue and substantial dialogue. Character voices are distinct and authentic to the setting. Ilyena speaks with aristocratic condescension, Katra is terse and practical, Simeon is earnest but anxious, and Aya balances her aristocratic upbringing with her criminal ambitions. The dialogue effectively conveys character relationships and tensions without exposition. The descriptive quality is a particular strength. Sensory details like "the brass rivets cold and slick beneath her palm," "the air stank of brine and machinery," and Ilyena's perfume that smelled "sharp and bitter, like wormwood" create a vivid, immersive world. The writer effectively uses imagery that reinforces the setting's industrial-magical fusion. The prose generally flows well, with varied sentence structures that create rhythm and tension. Occasionally, the writing becomes slightly purple ("twin shards of obsidian" for eyes), but these moments are balanced by more straightforward narration. The piece maintains emotional engagement through Aya's internal conflict and the mounting tension of their capture. The characters' actions are believable within the established context, and the ending avoids incongruent positivity, maintaining the grim tone established throughout. Some minor weaknesses include a few instances where the writer tells rather than shows emotional states ("Aya's heart plummeted") and occasional overwrought descriptions. The narrative is also somewhat predictable in its trajectory, though this is partly due to following the required story beats. Overall, the response is a well-crafted scene that successfully establishes the requested aesthetic, characters, and tension while adhering closely to the prompt requirements. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Gunpowder Rendezvous — Score: 85.2
Prompt:
Gunpowder Rendezvous Spike Spiegel & Revy Write a story where Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop) and Revy (Black Lagoon) meet in a seedy bar after both being hired for the same bounty. Their mutual attraction is complicated by their trust issues and competitive instincts. Include drinking, gunplay, and unresolved sexual tension that culminates in a motel room standoff. **Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop)** Spike is a laid-back bounty hunter with a dark past as a syndicate enforcer. He practices Jeet Kune Do and is exceptionally skilled with firearms. He's chronically broke, constantly hungry, and addicted to cigarettes. Despite his carefree attitude, he's haunted by his past and the woman he left behind. He has a prosthetic eye from a past injury that affects his depth perception. He's fatalistic to the extreme, often saying he's already died once. He values freedom above all else and dislikes attachments, though he secretly cares deeply for his crew. Famous quote: "Whatever happens, happens." **Revy/Rebecca Lee (Black Lagoon)** Revy is a Chinese-American dual-wielding gunslinger with unparalleled shooting skills. She's foul-mouthed, chain-smoking, and has severe anger management issues stemming from childhood abuse. She's known as "Two Hands" for her ability to accurately fire two pistols simultaneously. She drinks heavily and solves most problems with violence. Despite her hardened exterior, she has moments of vulnerability, particularly around Rock. She has a dragon tattoo covering her right arm and typically wears extremely short shorts and a black crop top regardless of the situation. Famous quote: "I'm not a good person, not a bad person. I'm just here." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
A ring of rust on Spike’s lighter suggests it’s been dropped in water more than once—probably in pursuit of a bounty, or just trying to outrun his own shadow. He sits at a sticky bar in Roanapur, nursing a glass of cheap whiskey. The joint is all neon rot and peeling wallpaper, smoke coiling thick across the ceiling fans. The bartender eyes him warily; Spike’s coat and easy slouch say “trouble” in any language. He flicks his lighter open. The flame wobbles, then steadies. He lights a cigarette, exhaling with the practiced boredom of someone who’s been disappointed by the world more than once. The door bangs open, and there she is: Revy, all swagger and scowl, hips cocked, a pair of Cutlasses riding low on her thighs. Her dragon tattoo gleams under the jaundiced light. She orders a shot, downs it, then slams the glass down so hard the bartender flinches. Spike watches her with his good eye, the other one glazed with that distant, haunted sheen. He recognizes the look—someone who’s seen too much, survived too much, and doesn’t give a damn about anything except the next paycheck or the next drink. Or the next fight. “Fancy seeing another foreigner in this dump,” Revy says, sliding onto the stool beside him. Her voice is rough, cut with New York street and gunpowder. “You here for the same bounty?” Spike smirks, cigarette dangling. “Guess that depends. You looking for a guy with a snake tattoo and a penchant for bad sushi?” She laughs, low and sharp. “Yeah. Bastard owes Balalaika two million. Figured I’d collect his head before someone else does.” Spike shrugs, swirling his whiskey. “Looks like we’re rivals, then. I was hoping for an easy night.” Revy leans in, eyes glinting. “Nothing easy in this city, cowboy.” She snatches his lighter, flicks it open, and lights her own cigarette. She tosses it back, just shy of his hand. “Nice lighter. Been swimming lately?” “Something like that,” he says, pocketing it with a lazy smile. “So, what’s your move? Shoot up the whole bar until someone talks? Or just break a couple of fingers?” “Don’t tempt me,” she growls, but there’s a spark of amusement in her glare. A commotion erupts at the back of the bar. Their mark, drunk and waving a pistol, standing on a table and threatening the patrons. Spike and Revy move at the same time—him languid, her coiled like a spring. Spike’s already ducking behind a table as shots ring out. Revy draws both pistols, flipping over a chair to use as cover, her grin wild. The mark empties his clip in their direction, splinters flying. “Cover me, cowboy!” Revy shouts, vaulting forward. Spike answers with a half-hearted salute and a wicked grin, firing a few rounds to keep the mark’s head down. Revy moves like a force of nature, bullets dancing around her. She gets close, pistol-whips the mark, and has him face-down before Spike can stub out his cigarette. They drag the unconscious bounty out by his ankles, drawing stares and muttered curses. Outside, the air is thick with rain and the distant thrum of gunfire. They dump the mark into the trunk of a battered sedan. “Split the bounty?” Spike asks, lighting another smoke. Revy wipes blood from her lip and grins. “Fifty-fifty. You’re alright, cowboy. Haven’t had this much fun in ages.” But the night’s not over. Spike’s not the only one with trust issues. As they count their cut in a grimy motel room, Revy’s eyes never leave his hands. Spike leans against the window, wind rattling the glass. “You always this tense after a job?” he asks, voice soft. She laughs, but it’s brittle around the edges. “You always this chill after getting shot at?” He shrugs. “I’ve been shot at by better.” There’s a pause—a beat where the air thickens, heavy with smoke and something else. Revy uncaps a bottle of rum, takes a swig, then offers it to Spike. Their fingers brush. Neither pulls away. He studies her, that lazy smile faltering for a moment. “You ever get tired of this?” She narrows her eyes, searching for a trick, for a lie. “Of what? Surviving?” “Of running. Of having to watch your own back every damn second.” She smirks, but it’s forced. “That’s life, cowboy. You don’t like it, get out.” He looks away, exhaling smoke, eyes storm-dark. “Already tried. Didn’t take.” Her laughter is softer this time. “Yeah. Me neither.” The air hums with tension. He steps closer, slow, giving her every chance to tell him to back off. She doesn’t. Their eyes meet—his heavy with loss, hers defiant and hungry. He touches her wrist. She doesn’t flinch, but her grip tightens on her pistol. “You trust me, Revy?” he asks, voice low. She snorts. “Hell no. Do you trust anybody?” He grins, close enough now to smell the gun oil and sweat on her skin. “Not really.” In a blink, her pistol’s at his chest. Spike doesn’t move. His own gun slides from his sleeve, pressing lightly against her stomach. They’re so close now, they can feel each other’s heartbeats—a standoff with guns and something hotter, sharper, burning between them. “You wanna test your luck, cowboy?” she murmurs, mouth inches from his. He smiles—a real one, bittersweet and dangerous. “Whatever happens, happens.” The guns don’t drop. The tension doesn’t break. In the half-light of the motel room, they stay locked in that moment—two broken souls in a city that doesn’t care, caught between desire and distrust, both knowing the night could end in bullets or something much more complicated.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures the essence of both characters from their respective universes while creating a believable scenario for their meeting. The author demonstrates a strong understanding of both Spike and Revy, incorporating their canonical traits, mannerisms, and psychological profiles into a tense encounter that feels authentic to both source materials. The writing excels at establishing atmosphere through sensory details. The "ring of rust" on Spike's lighter, the "neon rot and peeling wallpaper," and the "smoke coiling thick across the ceiling fans" immediately transport the reader to the seedy bar setting. The author maintains this atmospheric quality throughout, creating a noir-like ambiance appropriate for both characters' worlds. Character portrayal is particularly strong. Spike's "lazy smile" and fatalistic attitude contrast effectively with Revy's explosive energy and trust issues. Their dialogue feels true to their established personalities, with Spike's laconic wit playing well against Revy's aggressive banter. The author incorporates their canonical traits seamlessly - Spike's prosthetic eye, Revy's dual-wielding "Cutlasses," her dragon tattoo, and their shared smoking habits. The action sequence is economically written yet vivid, showing both characters' distinctive fighting styles without overexplaining. Spike's languid movements versus Revy's explosive combat approach creates a nice contrast that reinforces their characterization. The unresolved sexual tension builds naturally throughout the piece, culminating in the motel standoff that perfectly encapsulates their mutual attraction complicated by deep-seated trust issues. The final image of them with guns drawn while physically close is a powerful visual metaphor for their relationship dynamic. However, there are some minor weaknesses. The dialogue occasionally feels a bit generic for these characters, particularly in the middle section. While functional, some exchanges could have more distinctive flavor. The action sequence, while competent, could be more distinctive to showcase their unique fighting styles more vividly. The ending, while thematically appropriate, feels slightly abrupt. The tension is maintained but without quite enough resolution to satisfy the reader completely. This may have been intentional given the prompt's request for "unresolved sexual tension," but it leaves the reader wanting a bit more closure or a more definitive final beat. Overall, this is a strong piece that successfully merges two distinct fictional universes while maintaining the integrity of both characters. It delivers on the prompt's requirements for drinking, gunplay, and unresolved sexual tension culminating in a motel standoff, all while keeping the characters true to their established personalities. Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 5.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Folk horror: Útiseta — Score: 87.2
Prompt:
Fok Horror: Útiseta Write a chapter set in rural northern Sweden in the mid-1990s. Linnea, a teenage girl from Stockholm, has reluctantly moved to a small village with her parents after her father's job transfer. She's befriended Astrid, a local girl who claims her grandmother taught her ancient practices passed down through generations. Astrid has been introducing Linnea to "midnight games" that involve old rituals, convincing her they can use them to learn classmates' secrets or influence their behavior. Tonight, Astrid has convinced Linnea to participate in Útiseta—sitting out on an ancient burial mound at midnight to "receive knowledge from beyond." The chapter focuses on this single midnight excursion, the ritualistic preparations, Astrid's matter-of-fact instructions that mix teenage rebellion with eerily specific traditional elements, and the mounting tension as Linnea becomes increasingly uncertain whether they're simply scaring themselves or if something is actually responding to their presence. The narrative should maintain ambiguity about whether the strange occurrences are supernatural or psychological, while establishing the dangerous line they're crossing by treating ancient practices as entertainment. First person, past tense, told as Linnea's recollection of events in the present day (though this device should be largely transparent). 1000 words. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
I remember how the wind sounded that night—rustling through the pines above the mound, almost like someone whispering secrets just out of earshot. Astrid said that was a sign: the voices of the land, stirring because we were listening. I told myself it was only the trees, but even now, decades later, the memory crawls under my skin. We started after eleven, sneaking out the back door of my parents’ red house, the porch light pooling behind us like a safe harbor we weren’t allowed to return to. Astrid had a backpack slung over one shoulder, her boots crunching on the frost-stiff grass. She moved with the easy carelessness of someone who belonged here, while I kept glancing over my shoulder, half-expecting my mother to appear, arms crossed, demanding to know what I thought I was doing. The moon was thin and sickly, barely enough to see by, but Astrid led the way as if she knew every root and stone. “You have to be quiet,” she whispered as we reached the edge of the woods. “They listen for noise. If you’re respectful, they might answer.” I wanted to laugh—Astrid always seemed so blasé about these things, as if old legends were just another way to pass a Friday night. But her voice was different now; lower, serious. She had braided her hair tight, wearing her grandmother’s thick cardigan that smelled faintly of woodsmoke and something sharp, like juniper. The mound was a low, grass-covered swell in a clearing, ringed by ancient stones sunk deep into the earth. I’d seen it in daylight, but at midnight it looked different—older, heavy with a kind of waiting. Astrid stopped at the edge and took out her grandmother’s tin box. She opened it and pulled out three things: a stub of candle, a pinch of dried flowers, and a tiny, worn piece of bone. “We have to make an offering,” she said, as if discussing homework, then knelt and pressed the bone into the moss. The candle flame guttered as she lit it, the light barely holding back the dark. “Sit on the mound, but not on the top. That’s for the dead.” I tried to mimic her calm, settling onto the cold grass. My hands shook, though I told myself it was just the chill. Astrid scattered the dried flowers around us. “Now we wait. Don’t speak unless you have to. Think of what you want to know.” My heart beat loud in my ears. I tried to focus on something harmless—wondering if Jonas in my class really liked Emma, like Astrid claimed, or if that was just village gossip. But my thoughts kept circling back to the strangeness of it all: the dark, the stones, the candle’s trembling halo. The wind picked up, sifting through the trees. The pines whispered, just as Astrid had said they would. “Do you feel anything?” she murmured. Her face was half-shadow, eyes shining. “Sometimes they come as a cold draft. Or you’ll hear your name. Sometimes it’s just…knowing.” I wanted to say no, but the air did feel different—thicker, somehow, and laced with a prickling anticipation. My legs ached with tension. In the distance, an owl called, its cry echoing off the trees, and for a moment I thought I saw movement among the stones. A trick of the light, surely. Astrid’s rituals always had a way of making the ordinary seem charged with meaning. We waited. Time stretched, elastic and strange. The candle burned lower. I tried to imagine the people buried beneath us, ancient bones tangled in roots, their stories long forgotten. What would they think of two girls trespassing on their resting place, demanding answers for schoolyard crushes and petty slights? Astrid shifted beside me, pulling her coat tighter. “Last time I did this, I dreamed about a white fox,” she whispered. “The next day, my uncle found a real one in his traps. Gran said it was a gift, but he was supposed to let it go.” I didn’t know what to say. The wind rustled harder, and somewhere in the trees, a branch snapped. My skin crawled. I tried to steady my breathing, but each exhale seemed too loud. Then, very softly, I heard something. Not a voice, exactly, but a shape in the dark—a sense of presence, watching, waiting. The candle flickered. I stared at the flame, willing it to stay, feeling a chill creep up my spine. Astrid leaned closer, her hand finding mine in the grass. “Don’t be afraid,” she whispered. “They only answer if you’re brave.” But I wasn’t brave. Not really. I was angry—at my parents, at this village, at Astrid for dragging me here. And under that, I was scared, because sitting on that mound felt like picking a lock I didn’t understand. I squeezed her hand, and for a moment I thought I saw movement again—a hunched shadow at the edge of the stones, gone as soon as I looked. Astrid’s breathing changed. She was staring into the dark, lips moving silently. I thought I heard my name, but maybe it was just the wind, or my own frantic heart. Suddenly, the candle went out. Darkness snapped shut around us. I gasped, and Astrid squeezed my hand so hard it hurt. For a few seconds, neither of us moved. Then Astrid let out a shaky laugh, the sound brittle. “That’s good,” she said. “That means they heard us.” We scrambled up, gathering our things in silence. My knees were numb, and the world felt blurred at the edges. As we hurried back through the trees, the wind followed us, whispering secrets I couldn’t quite catch. Back in my room, safe under the covers, I told myself it was just a game. Just Astrid, just the wind, just nerves. But sometimes, when I close my eyes, I still feel that presence—watching, waiting. And I wonder what really listened to us that night, and what we might have let in.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures the folk horror atmosphere requested in the prompt, creating a tense midnight ritual scene that maintains ambiguity about whether supernatural events are occurring or if it's merely psychological suggestion. The first-person narration from Linnea's perspective works well, establishing both her present-day recollection and her teenage skepticism. The author skillfully portrays Linnea as an outsider to the rural community, contrasting her urban background with Astrid's comfortable familiarity with local traditions. This dynamic creates natural tension and establishes Linnea's vulnerability. The setting is vividly rendered through sensory details—the whispering pines, the frost-stiff grass, the thin moonlight. These elements contribute to the eerie atmosphere while remaining grounded in the physical reality of rural northern Sweden. The burial mound itself is described with appropriate weight and presence, becoming almost a character in the narrative. The ritual elements are handled with a convincing blend of teenage casualness and unsettling specificity. Astrid's matter-of-fact instructions about offerings and proper behavior on the mound feel authentic to both her character and the prompt's requirements. The bone, dried flowers, and candle create a ritualistic framework that's simple yet effective. The building tension is particularly well-executed. The author uses subtle escalation—from wind sounds to movement glimpsed at the periphery to the candle's extinguishing—rather than relying on obvious supernatural manifestations. This maintains the requested ambiguity while still delivering a satisfying sense of dread. The prose is generally strong, with effective imagery and a good balance between description and action. There are moments of particularly evocative writing, such as "the porch light pooling behind us like a safe harbor we weren't allowed to return to" and "the mound looked different—older, heavy with a kind of waiting." The ending successfully leaves the reader uncertain about what actually happened while suggesting lasting consequences. Linnea's final reflection that she might have "let something in" provides closure to the chapter while maintaining the ambiguity central to folk horror. Some minor weaknesses include occasional overreliance on familiar horror tropes (the extinguished candle) and a few instances where the prose becomes slightly purple. The dialogue, while limited, serves its purpose but doesn't particularly stand out. Overall, this is a strong response that fulfills the prompt requirements while creating an engaging, atmospheric folk horror scene with well-developed characters and setting. Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 5.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Physical-spatial: Therapeutic Boundaries — Score: 89.1
Prompt:
**"Therapeutic Boundaries"** Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a former professional athlete undergoing mandatory physical therapy after a career-destroying injury, harboring resentment toward recovery itself. Their physiotherapist is not only unnervingly attractive but also a former training partner from their competitive days who has successfully transitioned to a new career while the protagonist's identity remains shattered. We'll lean into the sexual tension of the scene by having her be attracted to him, but both of them attempting to maintain mental distance while being in physical contact as he shows her stretches & movements & manipulates her body, navigating the thresholds of pain. This scene MUST maintain complete physical coherence—every movement, stretch, and manipulation must be anatomically precise and spatially consistent. Paint an exceptionally vivid sensory picture through detailed attention to pain thresholds, involuntary responses to touch. Capture the suppressed, flaring tension of physical proximity, touch, and the controlled infliction of uncomfortable movements. Physical clarity is essential — readers must understand exactly what is happening with the body during each therapeutic technique. 1000 words.
Model Output:
He’s kneeling beside me as I prop myself up on the edge of the padded table, the vinyl sticking faintly to the sweat on my hamstrings. The room smells like eucalyptus and antiseptic, and the air is thick with the scrape of his voice—low, steady, professional. His hands hover, then settle firmly on my left knee, the ruined one, the one that cost me everything. I’m trying not to watch the way his forearms flex beneath the faded compression sleeves—electric blue and magenta, jagged with lightning bolts, absurd in this sterile place but so unmistakably his. “Let’s go through the modified hamstring stretch,” he says, already bracing my ankle in his palm, fingers wrapping around the bony protrusion. “You remember how this goes.” Of course I remember. We used to do these side by side, shoving each other for space, laughing through the pain. Now, I’m the patient—resentful, brittle, and he’s the expert, all smooth competence and unreadable eyes. He bends my knee to ninety degrees, careful, methodical, then guides my thigh so it stays flush with the table’s surface. His thumb presses into the back of my knee, right into the notch where the scar tissue knots up. I feel my breath catch, just a little, and I know he notices because his eyes flick up to meet mine, dark and sharp, before he looks away. “Tell me where it starts to pull,” he says. I want to tell him it always pulls. That I feel the drag of it even when I’m not moving, like a leash around my life. Instead, I grit my teeth and nod. He leans in, his torso angled over my leg, his hip brushing the table’s edge, so close his cologne—something clean, with a trace of sweat—slides over me. He straightens my leg, slow, precise, supporting the heel with one hand, the knee with the other, coaxing my hamstrings to lengthen against the memory of tearing, the sickening pop that ended everything. The stretch is a white-hot wire down the back of my thigh, burning from sit-bone to calf. My foot twitches involuntarily. He feels it, of course. “Breathe,” he murmurs, and his fingertips shift, easing the pressure just enough without letting go. He’s watching my face for signs of pain, and I resent that too—being so easily read by someone who once sweated and bled beside me, who now gets to be gentle with my failures. His hands are strong but careful, thumbs bracing the sides of my knee to guard the joint’s fragile new architecture. He brings my leg higher, just past the threshold where I want to yank it back. My hamstring seizes, quivers, and he holds it there, the stretch trembling between us. I squeeze my eyes shut, inhale through clenched teeth, and exhale in a hiss. “That’s it,” he says, voice softer now. “Hold for five. Four—” He counts, and I focus on the pressure of his hands, the heat of his palm cupping the back of my leg as if nothing has changed, as if he never left the circuit, never got out while I stayed until my body betrayed me. My skin remembers his touch—calloused, deft, the way he used to adjust my posture, a quick nudge between races. Now every movement is deliberate, impersonal, but my body doesn’t care. My body remembers. He lowers my leg, slow and deliberate, keeping my knee slightly bent to protect the joint. I flex my ankle, feeling the tremor in my calf, the tingling aftermath of the stretch. He gives my shin a brisk rub, a circulatory brush with the heel of his hand, and the friction sends a shudder up my spine. “Side-lying clamshells,” he says, already moving to the other side of the table. He gestures for me to roll onto my right side. I do, awkwardly, using my arms to maneuver the deadweight of my left leg. He slips a resistance band around my knees, his fingers grazing my thigh, and I feel the heat of his skin even through the elastic. I prop my head up on my fist, eyes fixed on the wall, refusing to meet his gaze. He kneels behind me, one palm steadying my hip, the other guiding my top knee upward against the resistance of the band. My glute burns almost instantly, a deep, aching fire. His hand spans my hipbone, thumb splayed along the iliac crest, anchoring me so my pelvis doesn’t roll. “Keep your hips stacked,” he murmurs, voice just behind my ear. “Don’t let your pelvis tip. Squeeze from here.” He presses two fingers into the muscle just below my hip, the gluteus medius, and it contracts reflexively under his touch. I hate that my body responds so easily to his instructions. I hate that even now, in this broken state, I want him to notice the way I move. My knee shakes as I lift against the band, and he slides his hand down my thigh, tracing the line of my tensor fasciae latae as if mapping the edges of my pain. I do ten slow reps, every one a negotiation with the ache in my hip, the heat of his skin against mine, the memory of old races and cold showers and what it felt like to be whole. When I pause, breathless, he moves to the foot of the table, kneeling so we’re face to face. “Last one. Hip flexor stretch.” He hooks one arm beneath my left knee, guiding my leg off the edge of the table so my foot dangles, thigh fully supported. He braces my pelvis with his other hand, thumb pressing into the ASIS, fingers splayed across my lower abdomen, holding me still as he draws my knee back, extending the hip. The pull runs deep through my groin, up into the tender scar tissue around my iliopsoas. I can’t help the grunt that escapes me, half pain, half something else. His eyes meet mine, searching, and for a moment we’re suspended—his hands on my body, my breath ragged, the air between us charged and thin. “Breathe,” he says again, softer now. His thumb strokes along my hipbone, the motion almost soothing, but I feel the tremor in his hand. He’s not immune, not entirely. The tension between us is a live wire, humming beneath the clinical choreography. He releases me gently, hands lingering just a moment too long, and I’m left aching—not just in the muscle, but everywhere memory lives. He moves away, making notes on his tablet, his sleeves bright against the white light, and I stare at the ceiling, swallowing the burn, the longing, the anger at what I’ve lost and what I still can’t let go.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative effectively captures the complex dynamics between a former professional athlete and their physiotherapist. The piece successfully maintains physical coherence throughout, with anatomically precise descriptions of therapeutic exercises including hamstring stretches, clamshells with resistance bands, and hip flexor stretches. The narrative excels at conveying the protagonist's resentment toward recovery while simultaneously exploring the sexual tension between the characters. The physical therapy session serves as an excellent vehicle for exploring these tensions, as it necessitates intimate physical contact while maintaining professional boundaries. The sensory details are particularly strong. The author effectively conveys the physical sensations of pain ("a white-hot wire down the back of my thigh"), the clinical environment ("the room smells like eucalyptus and antiseptic"), and the tactile elements of the therapy session ("the vinyl sticking faintly to the sweat on my hamstrings"). These details ground the reader in the scene and make the physical therapy session feel authentic. The protagonist's internal conflict is well-developed. Their resentment stems not just from the injury itself but from watching their former training partner successfully transition to a new career while they struggle with their shattered identity. Lines like "I hate that my body responds so easily to his instructions. I hate that even now, in this broken state, I want him to notice the way I move" effectively convey this complex emotional state. The sexual tension is handled with subtlety and restraint. Rather than being explicit, it's conveyed through small details: the protagonist noticing the therapist's forearms, the lingering touch, the charged air between them. This approach feels authentic to the situation and adds depth to the narrative. The piece maintains a consistent tone throughout—melancholic, tense, and introspective. The prose is elegant without being purple, with effective use of metaphor and sensory language that enhances rather than distracts from the narrative. One minor weakness is that the narrative doesn't fully explore the history between the two characters. While we get glimpses of their past relationship ("We used to do these side by side, shoving each other for space, laughing through the pain"), more specific shared memories might have added additional emotional weight. The ending effectively maintains the tension established throughout the piece. There's no resolution to the protagonist's resentment or the sexual tension between the characters, which feels appropriate given the constraints of the situation and the complexity of their relationship. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Historical fiction: High Seas and Low Vices — Score: 85.2
Prompt:
High Seas and Low Vices: British Naval Officer in the Opium Trade Character: Lieutenant James Merrick, a high-ranking officer in the British Royal Navy stationed in Canton, China in the 1830s. Once promising and decorated, now struggling with a severe opium addiction he hides from his superiors. Synopsis: Write a chapter following Lieutenant Merrick during a single day as he shirks his official naval duties in what has become a daily need to satiate the dragon. Told primarily in dialogue with the characters he interacts with. Focus on brief slices of his journey through the shadowy underworld of Canton: interactions with acquaintances, negotiations with local dealers, schemes and unsavoury jobs taken to fund his habit. Writing Task: Use rich sensory details to describe a day in the life of James Merrick. Write for a real sense of time & place while avoiding cliche. First person, past tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The morning smothered Canton in a thick, yellow heat. Even before the bells, sweat pooled at my collar and my cough—the one I blamed on the briny air—rattled hard in my chest. Copper at the back of my tongue. I pressed a kerchief to my lips and rose from the cot in my narrow quarters. The gunroom was empty. Another day, and my commission unmoored, drifting somewhere between the Queen’s business and the city’s shadows. My uniform, pressed just so, lent me a veneer of order as I made my way through the warren of the foreign factories. I slipped past the quartermaster, Mr. Hales, who eyed me with that hound’s suspicion. “Lieutenant Merrick, the captain was asking—” “Later, Hales. I’m off to secure provisions. My stomach’s a riot.” He wrinkled his nose as I passed, my boots squelching in alley mud. The stink of rotting fish and coal smoke pressed into my nostrils, sharpened by the faint sweet perfume that drifted from the opium dens coiled behind shuttered doors. Down Hog Lane, a beggar child spat at my boots. “Captain Ang Mo! You buy pretty girl?” she sang, mocking in pidgin, darting away before I could muster a retort. The Cantonese called us red-haired ghosts. This city had a name for every vice. In the gloom behind a silk merchant’s stall, I found Chiu, a wiry man with a mouthful of gold teeth and a fan tattooed on his wrist. He palmed a clay pipe as I approached. “Lieutenant. No uniform today?” he asked, grinning. “Orders are dull. I’m after the usual, Chiu. Quarter now, and I’ll pay double next week.” He clicked his tongue, eyes darting. “Double’s no good if you dead by then. You cough like old woman.” “That’s the sea air.” He snorted, plucking a lump of brown tar from a pouch, weighing it in his palm. “Sea air, you say? Then why you come inland?” I slid coins across the crate between us. “Don’t be clever. I’ve got a task for you. There’s a French trader on the Pearl who’s been skimming. I need a name. You find him, and my business remains yours.” Chiu’s gold teeth flashed. “Lieutenant, you play dangerous game. Frenchman got friends. You got only me.” “Then you understand our arrangement.” He folded the opium and coins into his sleeve, nodding. “You find me tonight. Lantern Alley. I bring name—and pipe.” I left without another word, the day’s heat already making my vision swim. My hands shook as I ducked into a teahouse, the inside cool and thick with the scent of jasmine. Mei, the serving girl, slid a pot before me. “You look pale, Mr. Merrick,” she murmured, voice soft beneath the chatter of merchants. “Your cough is worse.” I forced a smile. “The sea air,” I lied again, taking the cup in both hands to steady the tremor. “Have you seen Mr. Wong?” She hesitated. “He waits in the back. But today, he says, only silver. No more credit.” Wong lounged behind a curtain, his fingers heavy with rings. He studied me as a cat does a wounded bird. “Lieutenant. Trouble on the docks, they say. A shipment lost. Crewman dead.” His English was precise, each word clipped. “You know anything?” I shrugged, swigging tea to burn the taste of copper from my throat. “A storm came downriver. Men fall overboard in such weather. You have something for me?” He slid a lacquered box across the table. “You work for me tonight, I give you half now. The rest after.” “What’s the job?” He leaned in, lowering his voice. “A Dutchman in the next quarter. He owes me. You collect. No trouble, no blood. Just the money.” I hesitated, knuckles white around the cup. “And if he won’t pay?” Wong’s eyes were cold as jade. “Then you come back empty, and your account is closed. No more smoke, Lieutenant.” I took the box, tucking it into my jacket. “I’ll see to it.” Back in the street, the clamor of Canton pressed close—rickshaws clattering, coolies shouting, the clatter of mahjong tiles behind greasy doors. My lungs burned. The cough came again, thick, and I spat red into the gutter, cursing the sea, the city, and myself. I found the Dutchman in a gambling den near the river. He was a fat fellow, sweating gin, surrounded by sycophants. I sidled up to him, my accent clipped and Royal. “Mr. Klerk. You owe Mr. Wong. I’m here to collect.” He squinted, face blotchy. “You? A British officer? For a Chinaman’s debt?” I kept my voice low. “Aye. And I’ll not leave without it.” He laughed, thick fingers tossing ivory dice. “I pay when I want. Tell Wong he can—” I grabbed his wrist, harder than I meant, and he yelped, scattering dice. “If you value your fingers, you’ll pay now.” The den fell silent. He fumbled a leather pouch, shoving it into my hand, his eyes wide with fear. “Take it. Tell him it’s all there.” I left fast, the hush behind me swelling into nervous laughter as I pushed through the beaded curtain and out into the blinding day. By now my hands shook so badly I could barely grip the pouch. Evening came, and the city glowed under lantern light. The box from Wong pressed against my ribs. I slipped through Lantern Alley, the air thick with incense and the faint, sickly tang of opium smoke. Chiu waited in a doorway, as promised. “You have it?” he whispered. I handed him the pouch, and he palmed me a fresh pipe, the tar already packed. “Frenchman’s name is Duval. He stays at the Jade Pavilion. Be careful.” I nodded, not trusting my voice. The pipe was warm in my hand, promise and poison both. Chiu’s gold teeth gleamed as I slipped into the darkness, the city’s vices pressing close, and the dragon inside purring for its due. Tomorrow, perhaps, I would face my duties. Tonight, the sea air would bear my secrets away, copper and smoke tangling on my tongue.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures the degradation of Lieutenant James Merrick, a British naval officer consumed by opium addiction in 1830s Canton. The writing successfully establishes a strong sense of place through sensory details that evoke the humid, chaotic atmosphere of colonial-era Canton, with its "thick, yellow heat," the "stink of rotting fish and coal smoke," and the "clamor" of the city streets. The character of Merrick is well-developed through his interactions and internal thoughts. His addiction manifests physically through his persistent cough, trembling hands, and the taste of "copper" in his mouth—subtle indicators of his deteriorating health. The narrative effectively shows his moral decline as he moves from naval duties to increasingly unsavory activities to fund his habit. The dialogue is particularly strong, revealing character relationships and power dynamics without exposition. Each character speaks with a distinct voice—from Chiu's broken English to Wong's "precise, clipped" speech. The conversations feel authentic to the setting and period while avoiding stereotypical portrayals. The prose maintains a consistent tone throughout—terse, sensory-rich, and tinged with self-loathing. The first-person perspective allows readers to experience Merrick's rationalization of his addiction ("That's the sea air") while recognizing his downward spiral. The narrative effectively balances external action with internal struggle. Where the piece could improve is in its pacing. While the day's progression is clear, some transitions between scenes feel abrupt, and certain encounters (particularly with the Dutchman) resolve too quickly to build sufficient tension. The ending, while thematically appropriate, feels somewhat rushed. The writing occasionally veers toward purple prose ("the dragon inside purring for its due"), but generally maintains control of its metaphors and imagery. The piece successfully avoids romanticizing opium addiction or colonial exploitation, instead presenting a gritty, morally complex portrait of a man caught between worlds. Overall, this is a strong piece that effectively fulfills the prompt requirements while creating a compelling character study of addiction and moral compromise in a well-realized historical setting. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
