+ Young adult drama: Gone South — Score: 79.8
Prompt:
Young adult drama Gone South Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The air here is thick, sweet and humid, a syrup you have to force into your lungs. I’m still wearing my Tennessee flannel—stupid, heavy, sticky—and I have a duffel that smells like my old room, which is a smell I never want to be near again. There’s a saxophone somewhere close, rising above the chaos, and it sort of sounds like how I feel: wild, a little desperate, and out of place. I keep moving, because if I stop I’ll have to think. About Mom’s face, the way her jaw locked when I said the words. About how the phone was still in her hand, and the counsellor’s voice crackled out—“concerning behavioural patterns”—like I was a broken car part, not a person. About how I ran before she could say anything else. New Orleans is a riot of color and noise. Bourbon Street isn’t even real life. It’s like someone turned the saturation up until the world started to bleed. There’s a guy painted head to toe in silver, pretending to be a robot. A woman in a purple dress and a mask laughs too loud into her phone. The saxophone player’s case is open and somebody drops a five in, and the coins jangle with a sound that’s almost hopeful. I find myself drifting toward the edge of Jackson Square, where the crowds thin just enough that I can breathe. I sit on the curb, hugging my duffel. I have about thirty dollars left, and zero idea what to do next. “Hey. You got a smoke?” I look up. There’s a kid, maybe my age, maybe a little older. Short, wiry, with hair buzzed so close their scalp glints in the sunlight. They’re wearing ripped jeans and a T-shirt that says ‘DEFUND YOUR DAD’ in marker. Their eyes are sharp, like they’re measuring me for something. “Don’t smoke,” I say, a little too defensive. They smirk. “Didn’t ask if you should. Asked if you got one.” I shake my head, and they plop down next to me anyway, way too close. I tense up. Back in Tennessee, you don’t sit this close to strangers unless you want a fight. Here, I guess, the rules are different. The kid eyes my duffel. “You just get in?” “Yeah,” I say, trying to sound like it’s no big deal. Like I do this every day. They nod, like they get it. “I’m Jules,” they say. “Been here three weeks. You?” “Taylor.” Jules pulls their knees to their chest. “Where’d you come from?” I hesitate. Part of me wants to lie, invent some badass story, but then I remember: this is the real deal now. No more made-up drama. “Tennessee,” I say. “Ran away last night.” Jules whistles, low and impressed. “Serious. You got people looking for you?” I shrug. “Probably.” We sit in silence for a minute, listening to the saxophone. I wonder what Jules’s story is. I wonder if it matters. Maybe here, you get to start over. “You got somewhere to stay?” Jules asks. I shake my head. “Not yet.” “There’s a shelter by the river,” they say. “But you gotta get there early. Fills up quick.” I nod, pretending I’m going to check it out, but I know I won’t. I don’t want to be packed in with a bunch of strangers, all of us smelling like fear and old sweat. Jules seems to get it. “You hungry?” I nod, and my stomach growls right on cue. Jules grins and stands up. “Come on. I know a spot.” I follow. We weave through the Quarter, Jules ducking into alleys and cutting across courtyards like they own the place. They move with a quick, jumpy energy, glancing over their shoulder every few steps. I try to keep up, clutching my duffel like it’s a life vest. We end up at a little corner store. Jules grabs two bananas and a bag of chips, then flashes the cashier a crooked smile. “Put it on my tab, Mr. Roy?” The old man behind the counter sighs but rings it up. “You bring me that five you owe, or I’m calling your mama.” Jules just grins and winks at me. “He’s bluffing. My mom’s in Lafayette.” We eat on the curb, watching the world go by. It feels almost normal. Jules peels their banana, considers me for a second. “So, what’s your deal, Taylor? You look like somebody who just ripped the Band-Aid off.” I laugh—surprised at the sound of it. “You could say that.” “You queer?” Jules asks. Not mean, just direct. I nod. “Trans.” Jules bumps their shoulder against mine. “Me too. Welcome to the club.” I feel something loosen in my chest—a knot I didn’t know was there. Maybe I’m not as alone as I thought. “People here don’t care much,” Jules says. “Not like back home. Still gotta watch your back, though. Some folks got old ideas.” I nod. “It was bad back in Tennessee. My mom… she just looked at me like she didn’t even know me. Like I was some kind of alien.” Jules spits a banana seed into the gutter. “Parents can be assholes.” We sit in silence for a while. I let the saxophone music wash over me. “So what now?” I ask. Jules grins, flashing a gold canine. “Now we survive. Come on. I’ll show you where you can stash your stuff. Safer than dragging it everywhere. Then I’ll teach you how to make a few bucks.” I hesitate—trust isn’t easy, not anymore. But Jules feels real, solid, like someone who’s had to figure out the rules on their own. “Okay,” I say. “Lead the way.” As we walk, I realize I’m scared, yeah—but not just of what might happen. I’m scared because for the first time, maybe ever, I get to choose what happens next. The saxophone fades behind us. The city opens up, wide and wild, and I step forward, one foot in front of the other, into whatever comes next.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] The response presents a first-person narrative following Taylor, a trans teen who has run away from Tennessee to New Orleans after coming out to their family. The piece effectively captures Taylor's disorientation and vulnerability in a new environment while introducing Jules, another trans runaway who becomes an immediate connection. The writing demonstrates strong adherence to the prompt's requirements, maintaining first-person perspective and incorporating Taylor's internal monologue throughout. The author effectively establishes the setting of New Orleans through sensory details like the "thick, sweet and humid" air and the saxophone music that becomes a motif throughout the piece. Character development is handled well, particularly in Taylor's cautious approach to their new situation. The meeting with Jules feels organic, and their interaction reveals aspects of both characters naturally. Jules is established as streetwise but approachable, creating an interesting dynamic between the characters. The prose is generally clean and effective, with some particularly strong imagery in the description of Bourbon Street as "a riot of color and noise" where "someone turned the saturation up until the world started to bleed." However, there are moments where the writing relies on familiar phrases and descriptions that don't quite elevate the piece to exceptional status. The dialogue between Taylor and Jules is believable for teenagers in their situation, though it occasionally feels a bit too direct and expository, particularly when discussing their trans identities. While this serves to establish their connection quickly, it lacks some of the awkwardness or hesitation that might make such a conversation feel more authentic. The emotional complexity of Taylor's situation is handled well, balancing their fear and uncertainty with moments of tentative hope. The piece effectively conveys Taylor's conflicting emotions about their escape and new situation without becoming melodramatic. The ending strikes an appropriate tone of cautious optimism without resolving Taylor's problems too neatly. The final line about stepping "into whatever comes next" provides closure to this chapter while acknowledging that Taylor's journey is just beginning. Overall, this is a solid response that fulfills the prompt requirements and creates engaging characters in a well-realized setting. While it doesn't reach the heights of truly exceptional prose or surprising narrative choices, it successfully tells the story of Taylor's first day in New Orleans with emotional resonance and narrative coherence. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 15 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 14 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 6 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 16 Overall Impression: 16
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 16.0, Nuanced Characters: 15.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 14.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 6.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8.0, Amateurish: 5.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 3.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 16.0, Overall Impression: 16.0
+ Dystopic-comedy: My Apocalypse Buddy — Score: 83.2
Prompt:
My Apocalypse Buddy Write a wry, dry short story of survival and adventure loosely in the style of Terry Pratchett, set in the post-technological collapse world. The story begins with the pair deliberating their predicament and intent for the day's mission, details the ways in which the mission inevitably goes sideways, and returns them to home base in multiple ways, worse for wear. [characters] - the animo-tronic stuffed koala, Chewy, from some long forgotten before time - midas, our hapless protagonist, who has a knack for finding himself in the worst kinds of trouble. 1000 words.
Model Output:
**My Apocalypse Buddy** Midas woke to the sound of Chewy’s mechanical eyelids clicking open and closed, producing a noise somewhere between a cicada and a man with a bad cough. The animo-tronic koala was not, strictly speaking, alive, but after the Collapse, the definition of “alive” had become more flexible than Midas’s morals. “You drooled on my fur again,” Chewy rasped through his tiny speaker, which had become slightly more sinister after losing its bass in the Acid Rain Incident. Midas wiped his chin, blinking through the morning’s dust. “Consider it moisturiser. You’ve been looking… arid.” Chewy’s LED eyes flickered. “If I could feel, I’d be offended. But I can’t, so I’m not.” He flexed his stubby arms. “What’s on the agenda today, Captain?” “Same as yesterday.” Midas rummaged through his battered rucksack, pulling out a tin labeled *Chicken Surprise* (the surprise being that it was, in fact, chicken). “Find food, avoid death, and—if the universe is feeling generous—locate a place that doesn’t smell of burnt plastic and despair.” Chewy whirred thoughtfully. “I saw something last night. On the wall of that old train carriage. Graffiti.” Midas perked up. “Graffiti? You mean, the ancient art of misspelling and crude anatomy?” “No.” Chewy’s head swiveled. “It said, ‘Refuge lies beyond the Thorned Gate. Seek the blue hand.’ And then there was a drawing of a… well, it might’ve been a hand. Or a duck.” Midas considered this. “Quests are for people with options. We have… less than options.” “Technically, I’m not a person,” Chewy said, “so it’s your call.” Thus decided, they set out into the wilds, which were now less wild and more “selectively toxic.” The city’s bones jutted from the earth, draped in vines and the occasional aggressive squirrel. The “Thorned Gate” proved easy to locate—mainly because it was the only fence in a ten-mile radius still upright, and festooned with brambles thick enough to repel a particularly determined rhino. “I’ll boost you,” Chewy said, which was optimistic, given his entire body mass was equivalent to a family-sized bag of crisps. Midas snorted. “At least you’re not afraid of tetanus.” Thirty minutes, two ripped sleeves, and a string of new expletives later, Midas and Chewy tumbled through the gate, landing face-first in a patch of nettles. “That went well,” Chewy observed, picking thorns from his synthetic fur. “Better than last time,” Midas grunted. “Fewer bees.” Onward they trudged, searching for any sign of a blue hand, duck, or otherwise. The underbrush was thick, and the wildlife had evolved a taste for polyester and confusion. At one point, a raccoon attempted to mug Chewy for his batteries, but was scared off by Chewy’s war-cry (“I AM CHEWY, DESTROYER OF WORLDS!”), which echoed through the trees like a malfunctioning air horn. By midday, Midas’s stomach was staging a protest that could be heard from orbit. “If we don’t find this refuge soon, I’ll be forced to eat another tin of Chicken Surprise. I don’t think my insides can take the surprise.” “Look.” Chewy pointed with a stubby arm. There, painted on a ruined signpost, was a blue hand. Or possibly a blue duck. Imagination was required. They followed the trail, which promptly led them into a bog of questionable intent. “I hate this,” Midas muttered, as his boot squelched somewhere between mud and what was hopefully just more mud. Chewy, floating cheerfully on the surface due to his low density, said, “In adversity, we learn who we are. Apparently, I am a buoy.” Several hours, two detours, and one encounter with a flock of territorial pigeons later, they reached a clearing. At its center, a hatch in the ground, rimmed in faded blue paint. Above it, a sign: *SAFE HAVEN—KNOCK FIRST*. Midas exchanged a look with Chewy. “Think it’s a trap?” Chewy’s eyes flickered. “Given our luck, definitely. But it’s a new kind of trap. That’s almost refreshing.” Midas knocked. The hatch creaked open an inch, revealing the muzzle of a shotgun and a single bleary eye. “Password?” croaked a voice. Chewy leaned in, eyes glowing. “Duck.” A long pause. The hatch closed, several bolts slid, and then, with a groan, it opened wide. Inside was a cramped bunker, smelling of beans and desperation. The inhabitants—three people and a dog with half an ear—looked as ragged as Midas felt. They eyed Chewy with suspicion. “He’s with me,” Midas said, as Chewy attempted to look non-threatening, which was difficult for a talking koala with scorched fur. The leader, a woman with a buzzcut and an eyepatch made from a bottlecap, gestured them in. “You brought food?” Midas produced the tin of Chicken Surprise. The reaction was immediate and unanimous. “We don’t do surprises,” the woman said, and in unison, the inhabitants pointed to the ladder. Chewy and Midas found themselves ejected, blinking in the sunlight. “Better luck next apocalypse,” the woman called after them. They trudged home through the gathering dusk, silent save for the whir of Chewy’s joints and Midas’s stomach rumbling. At the Thorned Gate, Midas paused. “Was it all a waste, Chewy?” Chewy’s LED eyes blinked. “We didn’t die. That’s better than most days.” Midas scratched his chin. “True. Maybe tomorrow we try the other direction.” Chewy nodded sagely. “As long as it’s not uphill.” Their shelter—three walls and a tarp—never looked so inviting. Midas lay down, Chewy at his side, and for a moment, the world seemed less bleak. At least until the raccoon returned, this time with reinforcements. But that, as they say, was a problem for tomorrow.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This short story successfully captures Terry Pratchett's wry, dry style with its blend of absurdist humor, deadpan dialogue, and matter-of-fact approach to the bizarre. The piece effectively establishes the post-technological collapse setting through environmental details and character interactions rather than exposition dumps. The story follows the prompt's structure well, beginning with Midas and Chewy deliberating their predicament, detailing their mission to find the "Refuge," and returning them to their shelter "worse for wear" with a raccoon problem. The characters match the descriptions provided: Chewy is indeed an animo-tronic koala from "before time," and Midas demonstrates his "knack for finding himself in the worst kinds of trouble" throughout their misadventure. The dialogue between Midas and Chewy is a particular strength, capturing the dry wit and resigned humor characteristic of Pratchett's style. Lines like "Consider it moisturiser. You've been looking... arid" and "In adversity, we learn who we are. Apparently, I am a buoy" effectively convey the characters' personalities while maintaining the story's humorous tone. The prose avoids being overly purple while still providing vivid imagery. Descriptions like "the city's bones jutted from the earth, draped in vines and the occasional aggressive squirrel" and "the wildlife had evolved a taste for polyester and confusion" efficiently establish the setting while maintaining the wry tone. The story does have some minor weaknesses. The middle section could use more specific details about how the mission "goes sideways" beyond general obstacles. While the ending effectively returns them to their starting point with a new threat (the raccoon with reinforcements), it feels slightly rushed. The characters don't undergo significant development, though this is less important in a short, humorous piece focused on adventure rather than character growth. Overall, the story succeeds as a Pratchett-esque tale of post-apocalyptic survival with an odd couple pairing. It maintains a consistent tone, delivers on the prompt's requirements, and provides an entertaining read with several genuinely funny moments. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 15 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Emotionally Complex: 13 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 5 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 15.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 15.0, Emotionally Complex: 13.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 5.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Romance: Love in the Limelight — Score: 86.6
Prompt:
Romance: Love in the Limelight. Write one scene within a larger story set in Wales. A famous (fictional) actor ducks into a small-town bookstore to escape paparazzi. The scene takes us through the characters meeting in this odd circumstance. Over the course of the scene, the actor and the bookstore owner have a conversation charged by an undercurrent of unspoken chemistry. Write the actor as somewhat of a rogue with a fragile ego, which needs to be fed by having everyone like him. He is thoroughly charming, but the bookstore owner seems (at least superficially) immune to this; which paradoxically provokes a genuine attraction and derails the charm offensive. The bookstore owner, despite the superficial rebuffs of the actor's charm, is inwardly more than a little charmed and flustered despite themselves. Write primarily in dialogue, in the distinct voices of each character. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The bell over the shop door chimed violently, as though someone had tried to rip it free. Gwenydd looked up from behind the counter, a battered copy of *Howl’s Moving Castle* in her hand, just as a man in a soaked pea coat all but fell inside, slamming the door behind him. He pressed his back to the wood, breathing hard—a mess of dark curls, sharp cheekbones, and eyes that flicked immediately to her like a startled deer. Gwen recognized him, of course. Everybody did. Hard not to, when his face was plastered across the bus stop just three doors down. Rhys Llewellyn. The Rhys Llewellyn. He grinned, dazzling, like a spotlight had just flicked on in the dusky shop. “Afternoon,” he said, too loud, as if he were on stage. “You haven’t seen me, right?” Gwen arched a brow. “That depends. Are you about to rob me or buy a book?” He laughed, a little breathless, glancing over his shoulder. “Neither, unless you’re selling invisibility cloaks. Or—” He ducked as a camera flash pulsed outside the window, “—a rear exit.” She set her book aside. “You’ve got about thirty seconds before Mrs. Evans from the bakery next door comes in for her usual,” she said. “She’s got better gossip instincts than the Daily Mail.” Rhys’s eyes widened, concern flickering under the charm. “You’d sell me out that quick?” “I didn’t say I’d sell you out,” Gwen replied, folding her arms. “I just said you’re running out of time to be invisible. There’s a difference.” He edged away from the door, hands up in mock surrender. “Alright. I surrender. Please don’t feed me to the wolves, Miss…?” “Gwen. Gwenydd Morgan. This is my shop.” He seemed to like the sound of her name, rolling it around in his mouth. “Gwenydd. Pretty.” He glanced around. “And this is your kingdom, then?” She shrugged. “If you like dust and receipts for company.” Rhys advanced toward the counter, lowering his voice to a conspiratorial whisper. “I could hide in the stacks. Blend in with the Tolstoy. I give a mean brooding stare.” She snorted. “You’d last about five seconds before you started monologuing.” His eyes sparkled. “You wound me.” He pressed a hand theatrically to his chest. “That’s my bread and butter, you know. Monologuing.” Gwen was determined not to smile, though the corners of her mouth twitched. “You’re not on camera now.” Rhys glanced at the window, where the shadows of photographers hovered. “If I’m not on camera, do I even exist?” He tried to make it a joke, but it landed heavy in the stillness. She hesitated, feeling the sudden shift in him. “That’s a dramatic question for a Tuesday.” He grinned again, but it was tighter now. “Sorry. Occupational hazard.” He picked up a battered copy of *The Mabinogion* from the counter, turning it over in his hands. “You ever get that? Feel like you disappear when nobody’s looking?” Gwen considered him, taking in the restless energy, the way his fingers drummed against the cover. “Not really. I’m good at being invisible. Comes with the job.” He looked at her, earnest now. “What’s that like?” She shrugged, but there was a flicker of something in her eyes. “Peaceful. Most days. Some days a bit… lonely, I suppose.” Rhys nodded, thoughtful. “I envy that. The peace, I mean. I can’t seem to go anywhere without people wanting something.” He offered a lopsided smile. “Except you, apparently.” She met his gaze, steady. “I haven’t decided if I want anything yet.” He laughed, the sound echoing in the small shop. “Brutal. You know, you’re the first person today who hasn’t tried to take my picture, get my autograph, or—God help me—ask me to say a line from ‘Dragon’s Heart’.” He dropped his voice into a comically deep register. “‘With me, my brothers! For glory!’” She rolled her eyes, but her lips twitched. “That film was terrible.” He put a hand to his heart again, mock wounded. “You’re a menace, Gwenydd Morgan.” “I’m honest.” He grinned, looking genuinely delighted. “I could use more of that.” For a moment, the only sound was the rain against the windows. Gwen fiddled with a bookmark, not quite meeting his eyes. “So… why the running, really? Paparazzi can’t be the only reason someone ducks into my shop like their life depends on it.” Rhys hesitated, then leaned in, voice softer. “Sometimes it feels like if I stop… if I let them see I’m tired, or scared, or just not up for it, the whole thing will collapse. Like I’ll vanish.” He tried to smile. “Years ago, my first big role, I froze on stage. Couldn’t remember a single line. Stood there, sweating under the lights. The director hissed at me from the wings, ‘Just smile, Llewellyn. They love you when you smile.’ So I did. And they clapped. And I thought—maybe that’s all I need to do. Smile, and they’ll never know.” Gwen was silent, watching him. Her voice was quieter when she spoke. “You don’t have to smile in here, you know.” He looked at her, something raw in his eyes. “Are you sure?” She nodded. “I’ve got some tea in the back. And a chair. You can hide as long as you want.” He grinned, softer this time. “You’re not as immune as you pretend, are you?” She flushed, looking away. “You’re not as charming as you think.” He laughed, real and unguarded. “That’s a first. Gwenydd Morgan, you might be the only honest person in Wales.” She moved out from behind the counter, brushing past him toward the tiny kitchen. “Come on, then. Tea. But you’re washing your own mug.” He watched her go, a smile tugging at his lips, and followed—leaving his public self behind, if only for a little while.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures a chance meeting between a famous actor and a bookstore owner in Wales. The writing successfully establishes the setting and creates a believable scenario where Rhys Llewellyn, a well-known actor, seeks refuge from paparazzi in Gwenydd Morgan's bookstore. The dialogue is the strongest element of the piece. Both characters have distinct voices that reveal their personalities. Rhys speaks with theatrical flair, using dramatic language and gestures, while Gwen is more direct and unimpressed. Their exchange feels natural and builds tension effectively. Character development is handled well within the constraints of a short scene. Rhys is portrayed as charming but insecure, needing validation yet finding himself drawn to Gwen precisely because she doesn't immediately fall for his practiced charm. The writer effectively shows his fragile ego through both dialogue ("You're not as immune as you pretend, are you?") and the revealing moment when he discusses his fear of disappearing when not performing. Gwen's character is similarly well-crafted, maintaining a cool exterior while the narrative reveals her inner attraction. The prose is generally clean and effective, avoiding excessive description while still providing enough sensory detail to ground the scene. The writer uses physical cues effectively to convey emotional states, such as Rhys's restless energy and Gwen's flushing and avoidance of eye contact. The pacing works well, starting with the dramatic entrance and moving through stages of their interaction naturally. The scene builds to a moment of genuine connection when Rhys reveals his vulnerability about performing, which feels earned rather than forced. Some minor weaknesses include a few instances where the dialogue tags become repetitive ("he said," "she replied") and occasional moments where the characters' internal thoughts could be more subtly integrated. The ending, while satisfying in showing a shift in their relationship, could perhaps use a bit more tension or complexity to leave readers eager for more. Overall, this is a strong piece that successfully fulfills the prompt requirements, creating a believable romantic tension between two well-drawn characters in a specific setting. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17

+ Whalepunk fantasy: The Morska Conspiracy — Score: 84.5
Prompt:
Whalepunk fantasy The Morska Conspiracy The Morska thieves guild experiences a sudden power vacuum as its leader was arrested in a raid in the early hours of the morning. Aya, a young woman born into aristocracy, has a keen interest in both the sciences and the arcane, having inherited her mother's gift for immateria magick (an outlawed practice for which her mother was, regrettably, hanged by the neck). Aya, bored with the world of aristocracy, has been spending her nights moonlighting with this very guild (masked, naturally). Leveraging her latent ability to summon dark entities from the immateria, she quickly rose through the ranks of the guild. Now, recognising the opportunity of the sudden power vacuum, Aya and her close companions Katra and Simeon, make a play for heart of the guild's claim to power: an ancient scythan artifact, under guard of spell and key in the depths of the guild hq. In contrast with the desperate chaos they had navigated thus far, the entrance to the underhold felt suddenly too quiet. Aya braces herself and reaches for the door. Write the next scene as the trio enter the underhold and find themselves confronted by none other than the guild leader herself, decidedly *un*-incarcerated, and in possession of both weapons and bodyguards. Paint a vivid picture of of the confrontation. Story beats: Aya is captured and unmasked. The trio are captured. Aya attempts to stall their demise by negotiating on her value as a hostage -- as she grapples with the inevitable consequences of her role in the guild being brought to light. Incorporate dialogue in the authentic voices of the characters. Do not write a fight scene. Lean into the gritty Victorian aesthetic with the dialogue & worldbuilding, as well as elements of gothic horror. In this world, men trust brass and oil and steel; magicka is feared and barely understood. Write in third person past tense, incorporating both Aya's internal monologue, and a heavy dialogue component. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Aya’s boots whispered over the slick black stones, the hush of her companions behind her. The underhold’s iron door loomed before them, its glyphs smoldering faintly, the air thick with lamp-oil, whale grease, and the sharp tang of ozone that always came with the eldritch devices of the guild. The stillness was so complete that Aya could hear the blood humming in her own ears, each heartbeat a hammerstroke within her chest. The only sound from beyond was the slow drip of water—somewhere far below, a cistern collecting the brine that pervaded every brick of Morska. Katra’s voice, low and choked with nerves, broke the silence. “Feels like we’re walking into the whale’s mouth, Aya.” Aya forced a smile, though none could see it beneath her mask. “That’s where the best bones are, Kat.” She pressed her palm to the sigil-plate; the cold of the metal bit down to her bone, reading her pulse, her intent—her lie. The lock sighed open, and with a glance to Simeon, she pushed through. The passage yawned before them, damp as a tomb, lined with the whale-oil lanterns that twisted the shadows into wild, writhing shapes. At the far end, the vault door stood open, a dark mouth in the stone. Simeon tensed at her side, hand on his revolver. “Stay close,” Aya whispered, her voice trembling only a little. She drew the immateria to her, a silken thread in her mind’s grasp, ready but hidden. They stepped into the vault, boots echoing on the flagstones. The artifact—a carven scythan idol, all slick black curves and runes that seemed to crawl under the skin—sat upon a pedestal of bone and brass. But the room was not empty. From the gloom beyond the idol, a figure stepped forward, her silhouette unmistakable, even as the gaslight flickered over the sharp planes of her face. Guildmistress Ruvina, the Sea-Widow herself—her hair swept back with pins of whalebone, her eyes sharp as harpoons, her lips curled in a half-smile devoid of warmth. “Well, well,” Ruvina drawled, her voice like the creak of old ropes. “If it isn’t the little night-moth and her rats.” At her flanks, two brutes in oilskin coats raised their scatterguns, and behind them more figures emerged, pale in the lantern-glow, eyes glinting with oily malice. Aya froze—caught between bolting and bargaining, the immateria flickering at her fingertips. But Ruvina’s gaze pinned her to the spot. “Thought you’d slit the guild’s belly and take what falls out, did you?” The mistress’s boots rang on the stone as she stalked closer. “You think I’m so easily caged, child?” Katra spat, “We saw the constables drag you off. Whole street saw it.” Ruvina laughed, the sound echoing against the damp stone. “Constables are as easy bought as a dockside whore. I wanted the city to think me gone, so the rats would crawl into daylight. And here you are. Unmask her.” The two brutes seized Aya, wrenching her arms behind her back before she could react. Cold hands tore away her mask, and the gaslight fell upon her face—pale, aristocratic, eyes wide with terror and fury. Ruvina’s smile widened, sharklike. “Ah. The little Hamilton girl.” Her voice curled around Aya’s name like a noose. “Did you think your pretty face and your mother’s sorcery would keep you safe, child?” Simeon lunged forward, but a gun barrel cracked across his jaw, sending him sprawling. Katra was forced to her knees, her eyes wild. Aya’s mind raced—a thousand calculations, all for naught. The immateria, that dark, whispering presence, squirmed at the edges of her thoughts, but she held it back. Too many guns, too many eyes. Ruvina crouched before her, eyes like black pearls. “Tell me, Miss Hamilton—how shall I balance the scales? I have traitors, thieves, and a little witch. The city would pay handsomely for you—your father twice over, the constables tenfold. Or perhaps I keep you, let you rot in the dark, until the guild is whole again.” Aya forced herself to meet those pitiless eyes. “You need me alive. If I vanish, my father will turn the city upside down. The constables will swarm your operations. If you ransom me, he’ll pay—but he’ll never stop coming.” Ruvina’s gaze flicked to the idol. “And what of your little talent? The immateria runs in your blood, I hear. Your mother danced at the end of a rope for less.” Aya’s throat tightened; the memory of her mother’s execution swung before her like a pendulum. She swallowed the bile rising in her mouth, forcing herself to speak. “You know what I can do. You’ve seen it. Let me be of use. Spare my companions and I’ll serve you. I’ll protect the guild’s secrets.” Katra hissed, “Don’t trust her, Aya—” But Ruvina silenced her with a gesture. “Bold,” the guildmistress murmured, circling Aya like a crow. “But I wonder—is it loyalty, or fear? What would you do to survive, little moth? What would you give me?” Beyond the walls, a foghorn moaned—once, twice, thrice—echoing through the weeping stones of the underhold. Aya’s mind reeled. The city above was waking, the tides turning, and here she was, unmasked and helpless, her secrets bleeding into the cold air. She bowed her head, voice trembling. “Whatever you ask. I can summon things—things you’ve only seen in nightmares. Let me prove my worth.” Ruvina studied her, the silence stretching taut as wire. At last, she nodded to her men. “Bind them. Lock them in the lower crypts. I’ll decide their fate when the tide turns. And you, Miss Hamilton—pray your father’s gold is worth more to me than your blood.” Rough hands seized Aya, dragging her to her feet. As she was marched away, she caught one last glimpse of the idol, its eyes winking in the guttering light. The future narrowed to a single, cold point: survive the night, or join her mother in the dark. The stone door clanged shut behind her, and the underhold swallowed her screams.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] The response crafts a tense, atmospheric scene that effectively captures the Victorian-gothic aesthetic requested in the prompt. The writer has created a vivid underworld setting with sensory details that immerse the reader in this whalepunk fantasy world - from the "slick black stones" to the "sharp tang of ozone" and the omnipresent whale imagery. The scene follows the requested story beats faithfully: Aya and her companions enter the underhold, discover the supposedly incarcerated guild leader, Aya is unmasked, and she attempts to negotiate for their lives. The writer has maintained the third-person past tense perspective throughout and incorporated Aya's internal monologue effectively. The dialogue is generally strong, with distinct voices for each character. Ruvina's speech particularly stands out with its nautical metaphors and threatening undertones ("Thought you'd slit the guild's belly and take what falls out, did you?"). However, some of the dialogue could be more distinctive for Katra and Simeon, who have limited lines that don't fully establish their characters. The worldbuilding elements are well-integrated, with references to immateria magick, whale oil, brass and steel technology, and the social structure that fears magic. The writer has created a coherent sense of this world without resorting to exposition dumps. The prose occasionally verges on purple, with some metaphors that feel slightly overwrought ("The stillness was so complete that Aya could hear the blood humming in her own ears, each heartbeat a hammerstroke within her chest"). However, this stylistic choice generally aligns with the gothic horror aesthetic requested. The pacing is effective, building tension throughout the scene without meandering. The ending is appropriately dark and foreboding, consistent with the tone established throughout. The writer avoids a fight scene as instructed, focusing instead on the psychological tension of the confrontation. Character motivations are clear and believable. Aya's desperation and quick thinking in offering her magical abilities as leverage feels authentic to her character as established. The emotional complexity of her situation - caught between aristocratic and criminal worlds, haunted by her mother's execution - adds depth to the scene. Overall, this is a strong response that fulfills the prompt requirements while creating an engaging, atmospheric scene that leaves the reader wanting to know what happens next. + Fanfic-crossover: Gunpowder Rendezvous — Score: 83.0
Prompt:
Gunpowder Rendezvous Spike Spiegel & Revy Write a story where Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop) and Revy (Black Lagoon) meet in a seedy bar after both being hired for the same bounty. Their mutual attraction is complicated by their trust issues and competitive instincts. Include drinking, gunplay, and unresolved sexual tension that culminates in a motel room standoff. **Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop)** Spike is a laid-back bounty hunter with a dark past as a syndicate enforcer. He practices Jeet Kune Do and is exceptionally skilled with firearms. He's chronically broke, constantly hungry, and addicted to cigarettes. Despite his carefree attitude, he's haunted by his past and the woman he left behind. He has a prosthetic eye from a past injury that affects his depth perception. He's fatalistic to the extreme, often saying he's already died once. He values freedom above all else and dislikes attachments, though he secretly cares deeply for his crew. Famous quote: "Whatever happens, happens." **Revy/Rebecca Lee (Black Lagoon)** Revy is a Chinese-American dual-wielding gunslinger with unparalleled shooting skills. She's foul-mouthed, chain-smoking, and has severe anger management issues stemming from childhood abuse. She's known as "Two Hands" for her ability to accurately fire two pistols simultaneously. She drinks heavily and solves most problems with violence. Despite her hardened exterior, she has moments of vulnerability, particularly around Rock. She has a dragon tattoo covering her right arm and typically wears extremely short shorts and a black crop top regardless of the situation. Famous quote: "I'm not a good person, not a bad person. I'm just here." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The jukebox spits static and a tired riff, bleeding through the smoke-choked haze of the bar. Spike Spiegel leans back on a splintered stool, a half-empty glass of bourbon dangling loosely from his fingers. The neon signs outside cast sickly blue and pink stripes across his face, catching on the tired lines beneath his mismatched eyes. He’s already smoked through half a pack, the ashtray a graveyard of crumpled butts. He notices her before she notices him. It’s hard not to. Revy storms in like a summer squall, combat boots clapping on sticky linoleum, twin pistols holstered low on her hips. Her eyes cut through the gloom, sharp and predatory, scanning the crowd for trouble. Or maybe just for fun. She orders a bottle, not a glass, and drains a swallow before she even sits down. The barkeep flinches at her glare and retreats, leaving her alone at the counter. Spike watches her in the mirror behind the bar—her dragon tattoo twisting as she lifts her drink, the way her lips curl around the rim. He’s seen killers before, but she wears it like a badge. He slides off his stool and ambles over, casual as a stray cat. “You the one here for the McGrath job?” Revy’s eyes flicker, sizing him up. “Maybe. You the other asshole they hired?” Her voice is a low growl, all Brooklyn bite and gunmetal. Spike grins, lazy and lopsided. “Guess that makes us partners, huh?” She snorts. “Don’t flatter yourself, cowboy. I work alone.” He shrugs, lighting another cigarette. “Whatever happens, happens.” They drink in silence, the jukebox skipping through the same battered verse. The bar’s other patrons have started to notice—two predators circling, each wondering who’ll draw first blood. Spike keeps his hands where she can see them, but his posture is loose, practiced, every muscle ready to coil. Revy’s fingers drum on the bar, close to her holsters. “So,” she says, voice edged like a broken bottle, “what’s your angle? You look like you’d rather be dead than here.” Spike exhales smoke, letting it curl between them. “Death’s overrated. I just like the chase.” He glances at her with a crooked smile. “And you? You look like you’re here to start a war.” She tilts her head, mouth quirking. “Maybe I am. Or maybe I just wanna see if you’re as good as they say.” She leans in, close enough for him to smell the whiskey on her breath. “Think you can keep up, pretty boy?” He doesn’t flinch. “Depends. You any good with those toys, ‘Two Hands’?” Her eyes narrow, and for a heartbeat, the air crackles with tension. Then she laughs, throaty and dangerous. “You wanna find out?” The bar erupts in chaos as a trio of local toughs, mistaking the moment for weakness, decide to make their move. Spike is a blur—he ducks a wild punch, pivots, and plants his boot in one guy’s gut. Revy’s already moving, pistols out, twin flashes of chrome and thunder. She doesn’t shoot to kill, but her shots are surgical—kneecaps, shoulders, hands. Spike appreciates the restraint, even if it’s only to save bullets. When the noise dies down, bodies groaning on the floor, they stand back to back. Spike’s suit is rumpled, Revy’s lip is bleeding, but neither looks winded. “Not bad,” she says, holstering her guns. “Didn’t think you had it in you.” Spike flicks his cigarette away. “You’re not so bad yourself. For a trigger-happy psycho.” She grins, a flash of teeth, and for a second something soft glimmers behind her eyes. “Buy you a drink?” “Thought you’d never ask.” The bottle empties quickly. They trade stories, half-truths and lies, neither willing to admit how much they’re enjoying the company. When the bounty’s location comes up, neither is surprised to discover they’ve both been double-crossed. The job’s a setup—someone wants them to take each other out. They leave the bar together, the jukebox still whining the same old song. Outside, rain slicks the street in oily rainbows. They find a cheap motel nearby, more out of necessity than trust—there’s nowhere else to regroup, and too many eyes on them in the city. The room stinks of mold and stale sweat. They sit on opposite beds, guns on the covers between them. The silence drags, heavy with something neither wants to name. “Why’d you come in here with me?” Revy asks, voice stripped raw. “You don’t know me.” Spike lights another cigarette, his gaze distant. “Same reason you did. Figure if you wanted me dead, you’d have done it already.” She laughs, but there’s no humor in it. “I don’t trust you, cowboy.” He exhales smoke, eyes half-lidded. “Wouldn’t expect you to.” The air buzzes, thick with unspoken challenge and something darker. She stands, gun in hand, and closes the distance between them. Spike doesn’t move, just watches her with that lazy, half-amused smirk. Her voice is a whisper, dangerous. “I could shoot you right now. Take the whole bounty for myself.” He looks up at her, unafraid. “Go ahead. Might save me some trouble.” Their eyes lock, electric. For a second, the world narrows to the space between them—the blood on her lip, the smoke on his breath, the click of safety catches. She leans in, her gun pressed to his chest. His hand comes up, slow as sunrise, to rest against her wrist. Neither pulls the trigger. The moment stretches, taut as piano wire, unresolved and perilous. Then she pulls back, laughing, breathless and wild. “Next round’s on you, cowboy,” she says, and sits on her own bed, gun in her lap, eyes never leaving his. Outside, the neon flickers. Inside, the storm between them only grows.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures the essence of both characters from their respective universes while creating a tense, atmospheric encounter. The writer demonstrates a strong understanding of Spike and Revy's personalities, backgrounds, and speech patterns, weaving them into a narrative that feels authentic to both source materials. The setting—a seedy bar followed by a cheap motel—perfectly complements the noir-tinged world these characters inhabit. The writer establishes atmosphere through sensory details like the "smoke-choked haze," "neon signs," and "sticky linoleum," creating a vivid backdrop for the encounter. Character portrayal is particularly strong. Spike's laid-back fatalism ("Whatever happens, happens") and Revy's aggressive, confrontational nature are well-represented. Their dialogue feels true to character—Spike's casual, almost disinterested remarks contrast nicely with Revy's profanity-laced aggression. The writer captures Revy's "Two Hands" reputation and Spike's martial arts prowess in the bar fight scene, showing rather than telling their capabilities. The unresolved sexual tension builds naturally through their interactions. The writer avoids clichés, instead letting the tension emerge through subtle observations (Spike noticing how "her lips curl around the rim" of the bottle) and charged dialogue. The motel room standoff effectively culminates this tension without resolving it, staying true to both characters' trust issues. The prose is generally strong, with evocative descriptions and well-paced action. Metaphors like Revy storming in "like a summer squall" and the air "taut as piano wire" enhance the writing without becoming purple. The third-person present tense maintains immediacy and tension throughout. Some minor weaknesses include a slightly rushed transition from the bar to the motel and the somewhat predictable double-cross plot device. While the dialogue is character-appropriate, a few exchanges feel slightly generic for these distinctive characters. The bar fight, while well-executed, could have been more distinctive to showcase their unique fighting styles more thoroughly. The ending successfully maintains the unresolved tension requested in the prompt, leaving the characters in a standoff that feels true to their complex natures. Neither character undergoes any transformation that feels unearned—they remain essentially themselves, just slightly more intrigued by each other. Overall, this is a strong piece that captures the essence of both characters and their potential dynamic while honoring the noir-influenced worlds they come from. The writer demonstrates skill in character voice, atmosphere, and tension-building. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16 Elegant Prose: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 15 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 16.0, Elegant Prose: 15.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 15.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 5.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 16.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Folk horror: Útiseta — Score: 90.5
Prompt:
Fok Horror: Útiseta Write a chapter set in rural northern Sweden in the mid-1990s. Linnea, a teenage girl from Stockholm, has reluctantly moved to a small village with her parents after her father's job transfer. She's befriended Astrid, a local girl who claims her grandmother taught her ancient practices passed down through generations. Astrid has been introducing Linnea to "midnight games" that involve old rituals, convincing her they can use them to learn classmates' secrets or influence their behavior. Tonight, Astrid has convinced Linnea to participate in Útiseta—sitting out on an ancient burial mound at midnight to "receive knowledge from beyond." The chapter focuses on this single midnight excursion, the ritualistic preparations, Astrid's matter-of-fact instructions that mix teenage rebellion with eerily specific traditional elements, and the mounting tension as Linnea becomes increasingly uncertain whether they're simply scaring themselves or if something is actually responding to their presence. The narrative should maintain ambiguity about whether the strange occurrences are supernatural or psychological, while establishing the dangerous line they're crossing by treating ancient practices as entertainment. First person, past tense, told as Linnea's recollection of events in the present day (though this device should be largely transparent). 1000 words. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
I remember the taste of cold air that night, sharp as pennies against my tongue, and the way my boots crunched over frostbitten grass as Astrid led me through the fields. Even now, all these years later, I can still picture the little pocket torch swinging from her wrist, its beam bobbing over stone and shadow, making the world seem smaller, as if the darkness pressed in behind us like a held breath. She wore her father’s old army jacket, sleeves stuffed with wool, and a knitted cap tugged low enough to hide most of her face except for that determined little smirk. “We have to be quiet,” Astrid whispered, though the nearest farmhouse was a kilometer away and the only other sound was the wind combing through stunted birches. “If the spirits think we’re just mucking about, they’ll ignore us. Or worse.” She made it sound like a dare. That was Astrid—always so certain, as if the world bent itself around her explanations. I followed her partly because I was afraid not to. I was sixteen, an outsider in a village where everyone’s grandmother had once delivered someone else’s baby, where the old words still lived in kitchen corners and between the lines of the local paper. I told myself it was just another midnight game. Nothing more. The burial mound was low and broad, mossy, half-swallowed by the roots of a willow tree. Astrid said it was older than the church, older than our country, built by hands that never wrote anything down. We’d brought with us a wool blanket, a thermos of coffee that steamed in the cold, and a little tin box rattling with things Astrid called “offerings”—salt, a crust of rye bread, a lock of her own hair. She’d made me bring something too: a ring my mother gave me, back when we still lived in Stockholm, back when I thought the world was a bus ride away. Astrid spread the blanket on the mound, then crouched, tracing a circle in the frost with a stick. “Sit here. Cross-legged. Don’t let your knees go outside the line. If you feel something tugging, hold on.” “To what?” I asked, but she only grinned, teeth bright in the torchlight. We sat together, knees touching, and Astrid arranged the offerings in front of us. She poured a line of salt along the edge of the circle, her hands steady as she murmured something in a language I barely recognized. It could have been Swedish, or it could have been something older, twisted and worn smooth by centuries of repetition. The wind seemed to pause, listening. “We have to be patient,” she said, her voice suddenly softer. “You can’t force them. Just sit. Listen. Think about what you want to know.” “What if I don’t want to know anything?” Astrid shrugged. “Then think about what you’re willing to give up.” We waited. The cold crept up through the blanket, numbing my legs. I tried to focus on the questions Astrid had said we could ask—who spread the rumor about Elin? Why did Mattias never look Astrid in the eye?—but my mind kept drifting. I thought about my old room in Stockholm, the hum of traffic, the smell of warm laundry, the way my parents had argued in low voices before the move. I wondered if they’d notice I was gone, if they’d even care. Somewhere behind us, a fox barked. Astrid’s eyes flicked up, but she didn’t move. Then, just as my eyelids began to droop, the church bell rang. Once. Just once, echoing over the fields. Astrid stiffened beside me. “There’s no service tonight,” she whispered. The sound lingered, a shiver in the air. I thought I heard footsteps in the frost, slow and deliberate, but when I turned my head, there was nothing—just the willow’s branches stirring in the wind. I tried to laugh, but my voice caught in my throat. “Did you hear that?” I breathed. Astrid nodded, her face suddenly pale. “Don’t break the circle. No matter what.” The torch’s beam flickered. I felt something—a pressure, like the air thickening, pressing in on my skin. My heart hammered, and I told myself it was just the cold, just my imagination. But then I saw a shape at the edge of the circle: nothing more than a shadow, darker than the darkness, shifting against the grass. My hand crept to my mother’s ring, pressing it into my palm until the metal left a mark. Astrid began to chant, her voice shaking. I didn’t understand the words, but I felt them, as if they were being spoken inside my own head. For a moment, it seemed the mound beneath us was breathing, rising and falling with each word. The wind picked up, stealing the salt from the circle, scattering it into the night. “Linnea,” Astrid hissed, “give it your offering. Now.” I fumbled, dropping the ring onto the frost. It looked so small, so ordinary against the ancient earth. The shadow pulsed, stretched, and I saw—no, I only thought I saw—faces in the mist above the mound. Eyes, mouths, watching. The church bell rang again, though this time I was sure it was only in my head. Then, as suddenly as it began, the heaviness passed. The air snapped cold again, and I realized I was shaking, my teeth clattering so loudly I thought they’d break. The torch’s beam steadied. The shadow was gone. Astrid reached out, squeezing my hand. Her palm was clammy. “We should go.” We gathered our things in silence. I left the ring where it lay. As we trudged back through the fields, I glanced over my shoulder just once and saw nothing but moonlit grass and the shape of the mound, unchanged. But I felt different—emptied out, as if something had been taken, or maybe as if I’d left something behind. Later, lying in bed with the covers pulled to my chin, I tried to tell myself we’d only scared ourselves. That the bell was a trick of the wind, the shadows only tricks of the mind. But when I closed my eyes, I dreamed of the mound, and the faces in the mist, and the sound of a bell ringing out over fields older than memory. I never saw my mother’s ring again.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures the folk horror atmosphere requested in the prompt, creating a tense midnight ritual scene in rural Sweden. The first-person narration from Linnea's perspective works well, establishing both her outsider status and her present-day recollection of events. The writing excels in its atmospheric quality. The sensory details are particularly strong—the "taste of cold air... sharp as pennies," boots crunching on "frostbitten grass," and the torch beam "bobbing over stone and shadow." These details ground the supernatural elements in physical reality, creating the ambiguity the prompt requested. The characterization of both Linnea and Astrid is nuanced and believable. Linnea's motivations for participating—a mix of curiosity, loneliness, and desire to fit in—feel authentic for a teenage transplant. Astrid is effectively portrayed as the confident local who mixes teenage rebellion with genuine belief in ancient practices. Their dynamic creates natural tension. The ritual itself is handled with appropriate gravity. The specific elements—the salt circle, offerings including personal items, the chanting in an old language—feel researched rather than generic. The ambiguity about whether supernatural events are occurring or if it's just psychological suggestion is maintained throughout, with just enough unexplained elements (the church bell, shadows, the missing ring) to leave readers uncertain. The prose occasionally verges on purple but generally stays on the right side of evocative without becoming overwrought. Lines like "the darkness pressed in behind us like a held breath" create atmosphere without becoming excessive. The pacing builds tension effectively, with the ritual's climax arriving at an appropriate moment. One weakness is that the piece doesn't fully explore the "dangerous line they're crossing by treating ancient practices as entertainment" as requested in the prompt. While there's a sense of consequence (the missing ring, Linnea feeling "emptied out"), the narrative could more explicitly address the ethical implications of their actions. The ending effectively maintains the ambiguity while suggesting consequences. The final line about the missing ring provides a concrete, tangible reminder that something real happened that night, whether supernatural or not. Overall, this is a strong piece of folk horror that successfully creates atmosphere, establishes character, and maintains the requested ambiguity between psychological and supernatural explanations.
